title: What are API routes in Next.js?
content: API routes allow you to create serverless API endpoints inside the pages/api directory (Pages Router) or app/api (App Router).
explanation: Each file becomes an API endpoint, enabling full-stack apps without a separate backend.

options.text: Serverless functions in pages/api or app/api that handle HTTP requests
Only for client-side logic
Require Express.js
Not supported in Next.js

title: How do you fetch data in the App Router?
content: In App Router, fetch data directly in Server Components using async components and the native fetch() API with automatic deduping and streaming.
explanation: Next.js extends fetch() with caching, revalidation, and deduping—no need for getStaticProps or getServerSideProps.
sampleAnswers: Write async Server Components that call `fetch()` directly. Next.js handles caching and deduping automatically.

Example: `async function Page() { const res = await fetch('...'); const data = await res.json(); return
{data.title}
; }`

options.text: Write async Server Components that call `fetch()` directly. Next.js handles caching and deduping automatically.
options.explanation: Next.js extends fetch() with caching, revalidation, and deduping—no need for getStaticProps or getServerSideProps.

title: What is the difference between `resolving` and `fetching` in Next.js?
content: Resolving is determining which route to render. Fetching is retrieving data for that route.
explanation: Next.js first resolves the route (e.g., /blog/[slug]), then fetches data for it using Server Components.
sampleAnswers: Resolving matches the URL to a file in `app/`. Fetching runs the Server Component to get data and render HTML.
These phases enable streaming: the shell renders while data fetches in parallel.

options.text: Resolving matches the URL to a file in `app/`. Fetching runs the Server Component to get data and render HTML.

title: How do you handle authentication in Next.js?
content: Use NextAuth.js (Auth.js) for built-in providers, or implement custom auth with cookies, JWT, and middleware in API routes or Server Components.
explanation: NextAuth.js integrates seamlessly with Next.js and supports OAuth, email, and credentials providers.
sampleAnswers: Use NextAuth.js for quick setup with providers like Google, GitHub, or custom credentials. Store sessions in cookies for SSR compatibility.
In App Router, protect routes using middleware that checks for valid session cookies before rendering Server Components.

title: What is Next.js?
content: Next.js is a React framework for building full-stack web applications with features like server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation (SSG), file-based routing, and API routes.
explanation: Next.js simplifies React app development by providing built-in solutions for routing, data fetching, optimization, and deployment.
sampleAnswers: Next.js is a React framework that enables server-rendered, statically generated, and hybrid applications with zero config.
It provides features like file-based routing, API routes, image optimization, and middleware out of the box.

options.text: Next.js is a React framework that enables server-rendered, statically generated, and hybrid applications with zero config.
options.explanation: Next.js simplifies React app development by providing built-in solutions for routing, data fetching, optimization, and deployment.

title: What are the main features of Next.js?
content: Key features include: file-based routing, server-side rendering (SSR), static site generation (SSG), API routes, image optimization, automatic code splitting, and middleware.
explanation: These features enable full-stack development with optimized performance and SEO.

options.text: File-based routing, SSR/SSG, API routes, image optimization, middleware
Only client-side rendering
No built-in routing
Requires manual Webpack configuration

title: How does Next.js handle caching?
content: Next.js extends fetch() with automatic caching, revalidation, and deduping. Use cache, next.revalidate, and next.tags options.
explanation: Caching is opt-in via fetch options, replacing getStaticProps/getServerSideProps.
sampleAnswers: `fetch(url, { next: { revalidate: 60 } })` caches for 60 seconds. `fetch(url, { cache: 'no-store' })` disables caching for SSR.
Use `tags` for on-demand revalidation: `fetch(url, { next: { tags: ['posts'] } })` then `revalidateTag('posts')` in an API route.

options.text: `fetch(url, { next: { revalidate: 60 } })` caches for 60 seconds. `fetch(url, { cache: 'no-store' })` disables caching for SSR.
options.explanation: Caching is opt-in via fetch options, replacing getStaticProps/getServerSideProps.

title: What is the purpose of the 'use client' directive?
content: 'use client' marks a file as a Client Component, enabling interactivity, hooks, and event handlers in the App Router.
explanation: By default, all components in App Router are Server Components. Use 'use client' only when needed for interactivity.
sampleAnswers: `'use client'` at the top of a file enables useState, useEffect, and event handlers—turning it into a Client Component.
It should be used sparingly to keep bundles small and leverage Server Components for data fetching.

options.text: `'use client'` at the top of a file enables useState, useEffect, and event handlers—turning it into a Client Component.

title: How do you handle loading states in the App Router?
content: Use the loading.js file in a route segment to show a loading UI while data is being fetched. It works with React Suspense.
explanation: loading.js provides an instant loading UI without client-side JavaScript, improving perceived performance.
sampleAnswers: Create `app/dashboard/loading.js` that exports a component. Next.js shows it immediately while the `page.js` data loads.
This is built on React Suspense—no need for `useState` or `useEffect` to manage loading states manually.

title: How do you deploy a Next.js app?
content: Deploy to Vercel (official platform), Netlify, AWS, or any Node.js-compatible host. Vercel provides automatic SSR/SSG, edge functions, and preview deployments.
explanation: Vercel is optimized for Next.js with zero-config deployments and Git integration.
sampleAnswers: Push to GitHub and deploy on Vercel for automatic builds, preview URLs, and edge network caching.
For self-hosting, run `next build` and `next start` on a Node.js server—but you lose edge functions and ISR.

options.text: Push to GitHub and deploy on Vercel for automatic builds, preview URLs, and edge network caching.
options.explanation: Vercel is optimized for Next.js with zero-config deployments and Git integration.

title: How do you handle dynamic routes in the App Router?
content: Use dynamic segments like app/users/[id]/page.js. Fetch data using params.id in the Server Component.
explanation: The params object is passed to page.js, layout.js, and other route handlers automatically.
sampleAnswers: Create `app/blog/[slug]/page.js`. The `slug` is available via `params.slug` in the component: `export default async function Page({ params }) { ... }`
Use `generateStaticParams` to pre-render dynamic routes at build time for SSG.

title: How do you handle environment variables in Next.js?
content: Prefix with NEXT_PUBLIC_ to expose to the browser; others are server-only. Load from .env.local.
explanation: Non-prefixed variables are only available in Server Components and API routes—never exposed to client.
sampleAnswers: `NEXT_PUBLIC_API_URL` is available in the browser; `DATABASE_URL` is only in server code—keeping secrets safe.
Use `.env.local` for local development; Vercel lets you set env vars in the project dashboard.

title: What is the purpose of error.js in the App Router?
content: The error.js file defines an error boundary for a route segment, catching errors in Server and Client Components and displaying a fallback UI.
explanation: It uses React error boundaries under the hood and can be reset with the error.reset() function.
sampleAnswers: `error.js` exports a Client Component that receives `error` and `reset` props. It catches errors in the route segment and lets users retry.
Unlike Pages Router, error boundaries are file-based and automatically scoped to the route.

options.text: `error.js` exports a Client Component that receives `error` and `reset` props. It catches errors in the route segment and lets users retry.
options.explanation: It uses React error boundaries under the hood and can be reset with the error.reset() function.

title: What is the purpose of the `not-found.js` file?
content: not-found.js defines a custom 404 page for a route segment when notFound() is thrown or a route doesn’t exist.
explanation: It’s the App Router equivalent of pages/404.js but scoped to route segments.
sampleAnswers: Create `app/not-found.js` for a global 404, or `app/blog/not-found.js` for blog-specific 404s.
Call `notFound()` from `next/navigation` in a Server Component to trigger it programmatically.

title: What is on-demand revalidation in Next.js?
content: On-demand revalidation allows you to purge cached data and regenerate pages after build time using revalidateTag or revalidatePath.
explanation: It’s the App Router equivalent of ISR but triggered manually via API routes or webhooks.
sampleAnswers: Tag a `fetch` with `next: { tags: ['product-123'] }`. Later, call `revalidateTag('product-123')` in an API route to update the page.
Useful for CMS webhooks, e-commerce inventory updates, or admin actions that require immediate content refresh.

title: What is ISR (Incremental Static Regeneration)?
content: ISR allows you to update static content after build time by revalidating pages at a specified interval.
explanation: With revalidate, Next.js regenerates pages in the background when traffic hits them.
sampleAnswers: ISR combines the speed of SSG with the freshness of SSR. Use `revalidate: 60` in `getStaticProps` to update every 60 seconds.
It’s perfect for blogs, e-commerce, or dashboards where content changes periodically but doesn’t need real-time updates.

title: How do you implement nested layouts in Next.js App Router?
content: Create layout.js files in nested folders. Each layout wraps its child routes, enabling persistent UI like headers and sidebars.
explanation: Layouts are Server Components by default and can fetch data. They persist across route changes, improving performance.
sampleAnswers: In `app/dashboard/layout.js`, return a layout with a sidebar. All pages in `app/dashboard/` will be wrapped by it.
Layouts can be nested: `app/layout.js` → `app/dashboard/layout.js` → `app/dashboard/settings/page.js`.

title: How do you redirect in Next.js App Router?
content: Use redirect() from next/navigation in Server Components, or useRouter().push() in Client Components.
explanation: redirect() is for server-side redirects (e.g., auth checks); useRouter is for client-side navigation.
sampleAnswers: In a Server Component: `import { redirect } from 'next/navigation'; if (!user) redirect('/login');`
In a Client Component: `const router = useRouter(); router.push('/dashboard');`

title: How do you handle JWT tokens in Next.js Server Components?
content: You need to verify JWT tokens in Server Components. How do you do this?
explanation: Server Components can read cookies and headers. Verify JWT tokens server-side using libraries like jsonwebtoken.

title: What is the recommended way to store authentication state in Next.js?
content: How should you manage authentication state across server and client?
explanation: Store auth tokens in httpOnly cookies for security. They are accessible server-side and protected from XSS attacks.
